marvis.data

Data loading, processing, and embedding utilities.

Dataset Loading

Dataset loading and preparation utilities.

marvis.data.dataset.silence_pandas_warning(func, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Execute a function with pandas warnings temporarily silenced.

marvis.data.dataset.list_available_datasets() → Dict[str, int][source]

Returns a dictionary of predefined OpenML dataset names and their IDs. These datasets are known to work well with MARVIS.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping dataset names to their OpenML IDs

marvis.data.dataset.get_dataset_info(dataset_id_or_name: str | int) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get information about a dataset from OpenML without loading the actual data.

Parameters:

dataset_id_or_name – ID or name of the dataset to get info about

Returns:

Dictionary with dataset information including name, ID, feature count, sample count, target feature, etc.

marvis.data.dataset.load_dataset(dataset_name: str, bypass_size_check: bool = False, preserve_regression: bool = False) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[bool], List[str], str][source]

Load a dataset from OpenML. Can load datasets by name or ID.

Parameters:

  • dataset_name – Name or ID of the dataset to load. If using a name, it can be one of the predefined datasets (use list_available_datasets() to see options) or any other OpenML dataset name. If using an ID, it should be a string representation of the OpenML dataset ID (e.g., ‘1169’ for Airlines).

  • bypass_size_check – If True, bypasses the minimum 1000 samples requirement. Default is False.

  • preserve_regression – If True, preserves continuous targets for regression tasks instead of converting them to classification. Default is False.

Returns:

Features y: Labels categorical_indicator: Boolean list indicating categorical features attribute_names: List of feature names dataset_name: Full name of the dataset

Return type:

X

marvis.data.dataset.clear_failed_dataset_cache() → None[source]

Clear the cache of failed dataset IDs.

marvis.data.dataset.get_failed_dataset_ids() → List[int][source]

Get the list of dataset IDs that have failed to load.

marvis.data.dataset.analyze_dataset(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_val: ndarray, y_val: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, y_test: ndarray) → Tuple[Dict, Dict, Dict][source]

Analyze the class distribution in the dataset splits.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_val – Validation features

  • y_val – Validation labels

  • X_test – Test features

  • y_test – Test labels

Returns:

Class distribution in training set val_counts: Class distribution in validation set test_counts: Class distribution in test set

Return type:

train_counts

marvis.data.dataset.create_llm_dataset(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_val: ndarray, y_val: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, y_test: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, val_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, tokenizer: Any, prefix_start_id: int, prefix_end_id: int, class_token_ids: List[int], output_dir: str | None = None, num_few_shot_examples: int = 100, max_train_samples: int | None = None, max_test_samples: int | None = None) → Tuple[Dataset, Dataset, Dataset, LabelEncoder, str][source]

Create LLM datasets with TabPFN embeddings as prefix.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_val – Validation features

  • y_val – Validation labels

  • X_test – Test features

  • y_test – Test labels

  • train_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for training set

  • val_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for validation set

  • test_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for test set

  • tokenizer – Tokenizer for the LLM

  • prefix_start_id – Token ID for prefix start marker

  • prefix_end_id – Token ID for prefix end marker

  • class_token_ids – List of token IDs for class tokens

  • output_dir – Directory to save prefix data

  • num_few_shot_examples – Number of few-shot examples to include in the prefix (configurable at inference time)

  • max_train_samples – Maximum number of training samples to use (None for no limit)

  • max_test_samples – Maximum number of test and validation samples to use (None for no limit)

Returns:

Training dataset eval_dataset: Evaluation dataset test_dataset: Test dataset label_encoder: Label encoder for class labels prefix_data_file: Path to the saved prefix data

Return type:

train_dataset

marvis.data.dataset.load_datasets(args)[source]

Load datasets based on command line arguments.

Embedding Generation

Tabular, image, and audio embedding extraction and processing utilities.

marvis.data.embeddings.generate_dataset_hash(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, embedding_size: int, dataset_name: str = None) → str[source]

Generate a unique hash for a dataset configuration based on its properties.

Parameters:

  • X – Feature matrix

  • y – Labels

  • embedding_size – Size of the embeddings to be generated

  • dataset_name – Optional name of the dataset

Returns:

A unique string hash for this dataset configuration

Return type:

hash_str

marvis.data.embeddings.get_tabpfn_embeddings(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, max_samples: int = 3000, embedding_size: int = 1000, cache_dir: str | None = None, dataset_name: str | None = None, force_recompute: bool = False, task_type: str = 'classification', seed: int = 42) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray | None, ndarray, Any, ndarray][source]

Get TabPFN embeddings with improved class balance checking and caching.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_test – Test features

  • max_samples – Maximum number of samples to use from training set

  • embedding_size – Size of the output embeddings

  • cache_dir – Directory to store cached embeddings. If None, caching is disabled.

  • dataset_name – Optional name of the dataset for the cache filename

  • force_recompute – If True, ignore cache and recompute embeddings

  • task_type – Type of task - “classification” or “regression”

  • seed – Random seed for reproducible feature selection and sampling

Returns:

TabPFN embeddings for training set val_embeddings: Always None (validation embeddings no longer generated) test_embeddings: TabPFN embeddings for test set tabpfn: Fitted TabPFN model y_train_sample: Labels for the sampled training set

Return type:

train_embeddings

marvis.data.embeddings.get_embeddings_in_chunks(model: Any, X: ndarray, dataset_name: str = 'dataset', max_chunk_size: int = 3000, embedding_method: Callable[[Any, ndarray], ndarray] | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Process embeddings for larger datasets in chunks to avoid memory issues.

This function is designed to process large datasets in manageable chunks, reducing memory usage and preventing out-of-memory errors. It’s particularly useful for validation and test sets that might be too large to process at once.

Parameters:

  • model – Fitted model with get_embeddings method or custom function

  • X – Feature matrix to get embeddings for

  • dataset_name – Name of the dataset for logging (for informational purposes)

  • max_chunk_size – Maximum number of samples to process in a single chunk

  • embedding_method – Optional custom function to get embeddings (default: model.get_embeddings) If provided, will be called as: embedding_method(model, X_chunk)

Returns:

Processed embeddings as a numpy array

Example

```python # Using default method (model.get_embeddings) test_embeddings = get_embeddings_in_chunks(tabpfn, X_test, “test”, max_chunk_size=2000)

# Using custom embedding function def custom_embedder(model, data):

return model.embed_data(data, special_flag=True)

test_embeddings = get_embeddings_in_chunks(model, X_test, “test”,

max_chunk_size=1500, embedding_method=custom_embedder)

```

marvis.data.embeddings.resize_embeddings(train_embeddings, test_embeddings, embedding_size)[source]

Helper function to resize embeddings to target size.

marvis.data.embeddings.prepare_tabpfn_embeddings_for_prefix(train_embeddings: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, num_embeddings: int = 100, random_state: int | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Prepare TabPFN embeddings to be used as prefix, sampling from all classes. Ensures the returned class labels match the embeddings.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for train set with shape [n_samples, embedding_dim]

  • y_train – Labels for the corresponding train embeddings

  • num_embeddings – Total number of embeddings to include (not per class)

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducible sampling

Returns:

Array of shape [num_embeddings, embedding_dim] class_labels: Array of shape [num_embeddings] with corresponding labels

Return type:

embeddings

marvis.data.embeddings.get_dinov2_embeddings(image_paths: List[str], model_name: str = 'dinov2_vitb14', embedding_size: int = 1000, cache_dir: str | None = None, dataset_name: str | None = None, force_recompute: bool = False, batch_size: int = 32, device: str | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Extract DINOV2 embeddings from a list of image paths.

Parameters:

  • image_paths – List of paths to image files

  • model_name – DINOV2 model variant to use

  • embedding_size – Target size for output embeddings (will resize if needed)

  • cache_dir – Directory to store cached embeddings

  • dataset_name – Name for caching purposes

  • force_recompute – Whether to ignore cache and recompute

  • batch_size – Number of images to process at once

  • device – Device to run inference on

Returns:

Array of shape [n_images, embedding_size]

Return type:

embeddings

marvis.data.embeddings.load_dinov2_model(model_name: str = 'dinov2_vitb14', device: str | None = None) → Module[source]

Load a DINOV2 model for image embedding extraction.

Parameters:

  • model_name –

    Name of the DINOV2 model to load. Options: Standard models: - “dinov2_vits14”: ViT-Small with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitb14”: ViT-Base with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitl14”: ViT-Large with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitg14”: ViT-Giant with patch size 14

    Models with registers (improved training stability): - “dinov2_vits14_reg”: ViT-Small with registers - “dinov2_vitb14_reg”: ViT-Base with registers - “dinov2_vitl14_reg”: ViT-Large with registers - “dinov2_vitg14_reg”: ViT-Giant with registers

    Linear classifier variants (with classification head): - “dinov2_vits14_lc”: ViT-Small with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitb14_lc”: ViT-Base with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitl14_lc”: ViT-Large with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitg14_lc”: ViT-Giant with linear classifier

  • device – Device to load the model on. If None, auto-detects optimal device

Returns:

Loaded DINOV2 model

marvis.data.embeddings.prepare_image_for_dinov2(image_path: str, size: int = 224) → Tensor[source]

Prepare an image for DINOV2 processing.

Parameters:

  • image_path – Path to the image file

  • size – Target size for the image (DINOV2 expects 224x224)

Returns:

Preprocessed image tensor ready for DINOV2

Audio Processing

Visualization (Moved to marvis.viz)

Note

t-SNE visualization functions have been moved to marvis.viz.tsne_functions. This module reference is kept for backward compatibility.

Refactored t-SNE visualization classes to eliminate code duplication.

This module provides a clean class-based architecture to replace the duplicated functions in tsne_functions.py.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.TSNEGenerator(perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42)[source]

Core t-SNE computation and coordinate generation.

Eliminates duplication of t-SNE fitting logic across all the original functions. Handles embedding combination, perplexity adjustment, and coordinate generation.

__init__(perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42)[source]

Initialize t-SNE generator.

Parameters:

  • perplexity – t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • max_iter – Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducibility

fit_transform(train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, n_components: int = 2) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Generate t-SNE coordinates for train and test data.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • test_embeddings – Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • n_components – Number of t-SNE components (2 for 2D, 3 for 3D)

Returns:

t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, n_components] test_coords: t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, n_components]

Return type:

train_coords

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.BaseTSNEPlotter(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, use_3d: bool = False)[source]

Abstract base class for t-SNE plotting with shared infrastructure.

Eliminates duplication of figure creation, zoom logic, and legend handling across classification and regression plotters.

__init__(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, use_3d: bool = False)[source]

Initialize base plotter.

Parameters:

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level for highlighted points

  • use_3d – Whether to create 3D plots

create_plot(train_coords: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_coords: ndarray, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, semantic_axes_labels: Dict[str, str] | None = None, **kwargs) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

Create complete t-SNE plot.

Main plotting method that coordinates all the shared logic.

Parameters:

  • train_coords – Training coordinates [n_train, 2 or 3]

  • train_data – Training labels/targets [n_train]

  • test_coords – Test coordinates [n_test, 2 or 3]

  • test_data – Test labels/targets [n_test] (optional)

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight

  • semantic_axes_labels – Optional semantic axes labels

  • **kwargs – Additional plotting parameters

Returns:

Matplotlib figure legend_text: Legend description metadata: Plot metadata dictionary

Return type:

fig

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.ClassificationTSNEPlotter(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, use_3d: bool = False)[source]

Handles classification-specific t-SNE plotting.

Manages discrete class visualization with proper color mapping, class legends, and semantic name handling.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.RegressionTSNEPlotter(figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, use_3d: bool = False)[source]

Handles regression-specific t-SNE plotting.

Manages continuous value visualization with colormaps, color bars, and regression-specific styling.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.KNNMixin(*args, knn_k: int = 5, task_type: str = 'classification', **kwargs)[source]

Mixin class that adds KNN pie chart functionality to any plotter.

This eliminates the duplication between KNN and non-KNN variants of the plotting functions and provides pie chart visualization.

__init__(*args, knn_k: int = 5, task_type: str = 'classification', **kwargs)[source]

Initialize KNN mixin.

Parameters:

  • knn_k – Number of nearest neighbors to find and visualize

  • task_type – ‘classification’ or ‘regression’ for appropriate chart type

create_plot(train_coords: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_coords: ndarray, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, semantic_axes_labels: Dict[str, str] | None = None, train_embeddings: ndarray | None = None, test_embeddings: ndarray | None = None, **kwargs) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

Create KNN plot with pie chart layout.

Overrides the base create_plot to add KNN pie chart functionality.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.TSNEVisualizer(task_type: str = 'classification', use_3d: bool = False, use_knn: bool = False, knn_k: int = 5, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None)[source]

Main unified interface for t-SNE visualization.

This single class replaces all 14 functions from the original tsne_functions.py, eliminating massive code duplication while providing all the same functionality.

__init__(task_type: str = 'classification', use_3d: bool = False, use_knn: bool = False, knn_k: int = 5, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None)[source]

Initialize unified t-SNE visualizer.

Parameters:

  • task_type – ‘classification’ or ‘regression’

  • use_3d – Whether to create 3D visualizations

  • use_knn – Whether to include KNN connections and analysis

  • knn_k – Number of nearest neighbors (if use_knn=True)

  • perplexity – t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • max_iter – Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducibility

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level for highlighted points

  • cached_color_mapping – Optional pre-computed color mapping from resource manager

create_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, semantic_axes_labels: Dict[str, str] | None = None, **kwargs) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure, str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

Create complete t-SNE visualization.

This single method replaces all 14 original functions: - create_tsne_visualization / create_tsne_3d_visualization - create_combined_tsne_plot / create_combined_tsne_3d_plot - create_tsne_plot_with_knn / create_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn - create_regression_tsne_visualization / create_regression_tsne_3d_visualization - create_combined_regression_tsne_plot / create_combined_regression_tsne_3d_plot - create_regression_tsne_plot_with_knn / create_regression_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn - And more…

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • train_data – Training labels (classification) or targets (regression) [n_train]

  • test_embeddings – Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • test_data – Test labels/targets [n_test] (optional)

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight

  • semantic_axes_labels – Optional semantic axes labels

  • **kwargs – Additional plotting parameters (class_names, use_semantic_names, colormap, etc.)

Returns:

t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2 or 3] test_coords: t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2 or 3] fig: Matplotlib figure legend_text: Legend description metadata: Plot metadata dictionary

Return type:

train_coords

create_simple_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, **kwargs) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create simple t-SNE visualization (backward compatibility).

Matches the original simple function signatures that just returned coordinates and figure.

marvis.viz.tsne_functions.create_tsne_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_labels: ndarray | None = None, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False, use_3d: bool = False, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create t-SNE visualization of train and test embeddings.

DEPRECATED: This function is deprecated. Use TSNEVisualizer instead. This wrapper is provided for backward compatibility.

marvis.viz.tsne_functions.create_regression_tsne_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_targets: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_targets: ndarray | None = None, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), colormap: str = 'viridis', use_3d: bool = False, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

DEPRECATED: This function is deprecated. Use TSNEVisualizer instead.

Utilities

Utilities for loading and handling CSV datasets with precomputed embeddings.

marvis.data.csv_utils.is_csv_dataset(dataset_id: str) → bool[source]

Determine if a dataset ID corresponds to a CSV dataset rather than an OpenML dataset.

Parameters:

dataset_id – The dataset identifier

Returns:

True if this appears to be a CSV dataset, False if it’s likely an OpenML dataset

marvis.data.csv_utils.find_csv_file(dataset_id: str, search_dirs: List[str]) → str | None[source]

Search for a CSV file in multiple directories. Uses robust resource manager search strategy with fallback to legacy method.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id – The dataset identifier

  • search_dirs – List of directories to search in

Returns:

Path to the CSV file if found, None otherwise

marvis.data.csv_utils.load_csv_dataset(file_path: str) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[bool], List[str], str][source]

Load a dataset from a CSV file. Handles both single CSV files with features+labels and separate X/y files.

Parameters:

file_path – Path to the CSV file

Returns:

Features y: Labels categorical_indicator: Boolean list indicating categorical features attribute_names: List of feature names dataset_name: Name of the dataset (derived from file name)

Return type:

X

marvis.data.csv_utils.load_dataset_with_metadata(dataset_dir: str) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Load dataset metadata from a directory containing precomputed embeddings.

Parameters:

dataset_dir – Directory containing dataset files and metadata

Returns:

Dictionary containing dataset metadata including ID, name, is_csv flag, etc.

marvis.data.csv_utils.find_csv_with_fallbacks(dataset_id: str, primary_dir: str | None = None, data_dir: str | None = None, embed_dir: str | None = None) → str | None[source]

Find a CSV file using multiple fallback directories. Uses the new resource manager for robust path resolution.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id – The dataset identifier

  • primary_dir – Primary directory to search (e.g., current embedding directory)

  • data_dir – Data directory specified by user (e.g., –data_dir)

  • embed_dir – Embedding directory

Returns:

Path to the CSV file if found, None otherwise
